scenes.name: Nick's Reflections and Advice from His Father
scenes.summary: Nick Carraway contemplates the life lessons imparted by his father, setting the tone for his reflective and nonjudgmental narrative perspective.

emotion.quote: I've been turning over in my mind ever since.

scenes.name: Nick's Arrival in West Egg
scenes.summary: Nick moves to West Egg, expressing optimism yet feeling a sense of isolation in his new surroundings.

emotion.quote: It was lonely for a day or so until one morning some man, more recently arrived than I, stopped me on the road.

scenes.name: Dinner at the Buchanans
scenes.summary: An awkward dinner at the Buchanans' introduces Nick to Daisy's superficial happiness and Tom's domineering arrogance, foreshadowing conflicts to come.

emotion.quote: I was a guide, a pathfinder, an original settler.
I'm p-paralysed with happiness.
Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face.
Absolutely! I haven't heard a word.

scenes.name: The Revelation of Tom's Affair
scenes.summary: A tense moment reveals Tom Buchanan's affair, illustrating the underlying conflicts and the moral ambiguity of the characters involved.

emotion.quote: What you doing, Nick?
You did it, Tom, she said accusingly. I know you didn't mean to, but you did do it.

I couldn't guess what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I doubt if even Miss Baker, who seemed to have mastered a certain hardy scepticism, was able utterly to put this fifth guest's shrill metallic urgency out of mind.

scenes.name: Encounter with Myrtle Wilson
scenes.summary: Tom Buchanan displays his dominance and possessiveness during an encounter with his mistress, Myrtle Wilson, in the Valley of Ashes.

emotion.quote: We're getting off, he insisted. I want you to meet my girl.
I want to get one of those dogs, she said earnestly.
I can't complain, answered Wilson unconvincingly.

scenes.name: The Party in the Apartment
scenes.summary: A chaotic party in Myrtle's New York apartment ends violently, highlighting the destructive nature of Tom and Myrtle's relationship.

emotion.quote: I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.
With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change.
Daisy! Daisy! Daisy! shouted Mrs. Wilson. I'll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai— Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.

scenes.name: Gatsby's Lavish Party
scenes.summary: Nick attends one of Gatsby's extravagant parties, capturing the opulence and enigmatic aura of his neighbor's lifestyle.

emotion.quote: The honour would be entirely Gatsby's, it said, if I would attend his 'little party' that night.
I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited.

emotion.description: Superficial fascination combined with a deeper discontent
emotion.quote: I've never met so many celebrities. I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.
Hello! I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.

scenes.name: Rumors About Gatsby
scenes.summary: Gatsby's party guests speculate wildly about their host's mysterious past, demonstrating the rampant gossip and intrigue surrounding Gatsby.

emotion.quote: 'Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.'
I hadn't heard it and I doubted if there was any foundation for it.

scenes.name: Nick's Encounter with Gatsby
scenes.summary: Nick meets Gatsby, finding him to be gracious and charming, yet surrounded by an air of mystery.

emotion.quote: He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly.
It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it.
I've just heard the most amazing thing... and here I am tantalizing you.

scenes.name: After the Party
scenes.summary: Gatsby shares moments of pride and aloofness with Nick after the party, revealing his complex character.

emotion.quote: He was looking at an elegant young rough-neck, a year or two over thirty.
Somehow it seemed a great deal of effort to begin an intrusion into Gatsby's life.

scenes.name: A Drive with Gatsby
scenes.summary: Gatsby attempts to impress Nick with his luxurious car and hints at his affluent but mysterious lifestyle during a drive together.

emotion.quote: 'It's pretty, isn't it, old sport?'
He saw me looking with admiration at his car.

scenes.name: Lunch in New York
scenes.summary: Gatsby introduces Nick to his enigmatic world during a lunch in New York, filled with hints of mystery and intrigue.

emotion.quote: 'We're going to lunch,' said Gatsby.
'I thought we'd be here at the restaurant.'

scenes.name: Revelation of Gatsby's Past
scenes.summary: Gatsby's attempts to legitimize his past to Nick in his mansion, amidst doubts and curiosities.

emotion.quote: 'Look here, this is a bona fide piece of printed matter.'
'This fella's a regular Belasco. It's a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism!'
I was amazed to find that I had no idea at all.

scenes.name: The Party Continues
scenes.summary: The lively atmosphere at Gatsby's party continues, with Gatsby playing the gracious host amidst his quest for Daisy's affection.

emotion.quote: Gatsby, his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom.
Voices were singing and the sound of a vast tambourine shuttered through the air.
I found myself on Gatsby's side, and alone.

scenes.name: Aftermath of the Party
scenes.summary: In the quiet aftermath of the party, Gatsby's solitary reflection reveals his deep-seated loneliness and unfulfilled desires.

emotion.quote: Gatsby was standing alone on the marble steps, looking over the party's remnants.
I couldn't help but wonder what Gatsby was thinking as he stood there alone.

scenes.name: Gatsby Opens Up to Nick
scenes.summary: During a drive, Gatsby confides in Nick, revealing more about his past and vulnerabilities in a bid for understanding.

emotion.quote: He spoke earnestly and I could see a hint of vulnerability in his eyes.
His story was unlike anything I'd expected, and I found myself drawn in, wanting to understand more.

scenes.name: The Plaza Hotel Confrontation
scenes.summary: A heated confrontation at the Plaza Hotel brings tensions to a head, revealing the deep-seated conflicts among the characters.

emotion.quote: His voice was firm and filled with tension as he demanded Tom to acknowledge his relationship with Daisy.
Tom's face reddened with anger as he denied Gatsby's accusations and attacked his character.
She looked from Tom to Gatsby, and then back at Tom again, her expression filled with distress and indecision.
I felt caught in the middle of a deeply personal conflict, unsure of my place or how to alleviate the tension.

scenes.name: The Tragic Climax
scenes.summary: A fatal accident in the Valley of Ashes sets off a chain of events that culminate in tragedy, underscoring the novel's themes of loss and consequence.

emotion.quote: Wilson's grief was palpable, his eyes hollow with the shock of his loss.
The gravity of the situation was overwhelming, leaving me feeling helpless and deeply saddened.
Despite not being his fault, Gatsby's concern was for Daisy's involvement and the potential consequences for her.

scenes.name: The Aftermath and Gatsby's Resolve
scenes.summary: Gatsby's tragic end in his pool reflects the ultimate failure of his dreams and the hollowness of his pursuit of Daisy.

emotion.quote: Seeing Gatsby's lifeless body, I couldn't help but reflect on the hollowness of his pursuit and the price he paid.
Even to the end, Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us.

scenes.name: Nick's Lament and Farewell to Gatsby
scenes.summary: Gatsby's poorly attended funeral leads Nick to lament the ephemeral nature of Gatsby's life and relationships.

emotion.quote: It was an empty, solemn event, reflecting the transient nature of Gatsby's relationships and the superficiality of the world he had sought to belong to.
'The poor son-of-a-bitch,' he muttered. There was genuine sorrow in his voice, a rare moment of humanity in the midst of widespread indifference.
I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.

scenes.name: Nick's Reflection and Departure
scenes.summary: Disillusioned with the East, Nick decides to return to the Midwest, reflecting on the lessons learned from his experiences.

emotion.quote: I saw the East as a grotesque, distorted place, far removed from the ideals I once held. It was time to go home.

locations.quote: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. [...] That's my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family's name.

My house was at the very tip of the egg, only fifty yards from the Sound, and squeezed between two huge places that rented for twelve or fifteen thousand a season. [...] My own house was an eyesore, but it was a small eyesore, and it had been overlooked, so I had a view of the water, a partial view of my neighbour's lawn, and the consoling proximity of millionaires—all for eighty dollars a month.

Their house was even more elaborate than I expected, a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and ran towards the front door for a quarter of a mile, jumping over sundials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run.

This is a valley of ashes—a fantastic farm where ashes grow like wheat into ridges and hills and grotesque gardens; where ashes take the forms of houses and chimneys and rising smoke and, finally, with a transcendent effort, of ash-grey men, who move dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air.

The apartment was on the top floor—a small living-room, a small dining-room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living-room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, apparently a hen sitting on a blurred rock. Looked at from a distance, however, the hen resolved itself into a bonnet, and the countenance of a stout old lady beamed down into the room. Several old copies of Town Tattle lay on the table together with a copy of Simon Called Peter, and some of the small scandal magazines of Broadway.

The one on my right was a colossal affair by any standard—it was a factual imitation of some Hôtel de Ville in Normandy, with a tower on one side, spanking new under a thin beard of raw ivy, and a marble swimming pool, and more than forty acres of lawn and garden. It was Gatsby's mansion.

characters.quote: Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known.
He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it.
Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face.
Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.

'I married him because I thought he was a gentleman,' she said finally. 'I thought he knew something about breeding, but he wasn't fit to lick my shoe... The only crazy I was was when I married him. I knew right away I made a mistake.'
He was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby's house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there.
I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby's books in the library one night three months before... 'The poor son-of-a-bitch,' he said.

For a while I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and then in midsummer I found her again. At first I was flattered to go places with her, because she was a golf champion, and everyone knew her name. Then it was something more. I wasn't actually in love, but I felt a sort of tender curiosity.
